snippet: Russia invited both the Syrian foreign minister and opposition representatives to Moscow for talks this month and warned foreign sympathizers of armed rebels not to supply them with more weapons.
abstract: Russia, the most powerful supporter of Syria’s embattled government, takes new steps to exert its diplomatic influence over the violent conflict there, inviting both the Syrian foreign minister and representatives of the opposition to Moscow for talks and warning foreign sympathizers of armed rebels not to supply them with more weapons.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and RICK GLADSTONE
byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, Lebanon, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Alan Cowell contributed reporting from London, and Hwaida Saad from Beirut. An employee of the New York Times contributed reporting from Saqba, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Russia invited both the Syrian foreign minister and opposition representatives to Moscow for talks this month and warned foreign sympathizers of armed rebels not to supply them with more weapons.

headline.main: Russia Seeks to Exert More Influence Over Syria Conflict
headline.print_headline: Syria: Russia Proposes Talks, Conflicting Reports on Cease-Fire
